qas.question: What type of legal system is the Philippines officially?
The high court in The Philippines is modeled after what judicial body?
What document grants the Philippines Supreme Court the right of judicial review?
How many justices make up the Philippines Supreme Court?
When all judges of a court hear a case at once it is called?
What nation's court is the American Supreme Court heavily modeled after?
In addition to the Philippines, what country was Spain colonized by?

plausible_answers.text: "form part of the law of the land"

qas.question: What does the Philippine Statute Code state about the decisions of the Supreme Court?

context: While the <b5_0>Philippines<b5_0/> is generally considered <a0_0>a civil law nation<a0_0/>, its Supreme Court is heavily modelled after <a1_0>the American Supreme Court<a1_0/>. This can be attributed to the fact that the Philippines was colonized by both Spain and the <b6_0>United States<b6_0/>, and the system of laws of both nations strongly influenced the development of Philippine laws and jurisprudence. Even as the body of Philippine laws remain mostly codified, the Philippine Civil Code expressly recognizes that decisions of the Supreme Court <b8_0>"form part of the law of the land"<b8_0/>, belonging to the same class as statutes. The <a2_0>1987 <b7_0>Philippine Constitution<b7_0/><a2_0/> also explicitly grants to the Supreme Court the power of judicial review over laws and executive actions. The Supreme Court is composed of <a3_0>1 Chief Justice and 14 Associate Justices<a3_0/>. The court sits either <a4_0>en banc<a4_0/> or in divisions, depending on the nature of the case to be decided.
